[Music]
hey there's leslie samuel here from
interactive biology where we're making
biology fun and i gotta tell you your
immune system is pretty awesome it
protects you from so much and is a huge
part of why you're able to be here
watching this video right now now with
the immune response there's a
non-specific response where your immune
system is trying to get rid of whatever
foreign invader is in there without any
regard to the specific pathogen it's bad
so let's get rid of it and then there's
the adaptive immune response where you
are recognizing specific pathogens and
mounting an immune response against them
this adaptive immune responds where
you're acquiring immunity against
specific pathogens is what we want to
break down into four different
categories first let's break it down
into the two main categories there's
active immunity and there's passive
immunity in active immunity your immune
system is developing the antibodies that
are needed to fight off a particular
pathogen or infection in passive
immunity the antibodies are transferred
into your body from another source so
with active your body is actively
developing immunological memory and with
passive you're getting stuff but you're
getting it from another source now let's
break down these two main categories
both of them can be either natural or
artificial so for active immunity that's
naturally acquired this requires you to
get infected with the pathogen and your
immune system will then mount an immune
response and develop the antibodies to
fight against that specific pathogen
with artificially acquired active
immunity this is when we're dealing with
something like a vaccine you get a
vaccine for influenza measles covad etc
your body then actively develops the
antibodies to fight against that
specific pathogen that's artificially
acquired active immunity okay now let's
look at the two types of passive
immunity how would you acquire passive
immunity naturally well that's what
we're dealing with during the
development of a fetus they're
antibodies that are present in the
mother's blood that gets transferred to
the developing fetus via the placenta
the immune system from the fetus didn't
actively create those antibodies the
fetus just got those antibodies
passively but in a natural way another
way this happens is during breastfeeding
antibodies are present in the breast
milk and are passed on to the baby it's
a natural process and it provides a
level of protection against infection
the baby will have immunological memory
to fight off certain diseases in these
two instances but it got them passively
from mommy it's a beautiful thing now
with artificially acquired passive
immunity this usually involves injecting
antibodies that were taken from
individuals or animals that were
previously exposed to the specific
pathogen for example with covid one form
of treatment involved injecting
monoclonal antibodies from people who
were previously infected or from mice
and using their antibodies to help fight
against covid these kinds of treatments
are often used when your body doesn't
have the time to develop the antibodies
because you've already contracted the
illness now the downside to passive
immunity in both cases both natural and
artificial is that your body itself
isn't developing the antibodies so the
positive effects that you might get
lasts for a shorter period but those are
the four types of immunity we have
active and passive immunity both of
which have natural and artificial
sources my name is leslie samuel from
